sub_title: PhD candidate Palaeobiology of Thalattosauriformes at University of Zurich
summary: Working on Mesozoic vertebrates from non-avian dinosaurs to marine reptiles. Occupied with research, preparation and/or restoration of vertebrates, and education & outreach. Projects include paleopathological studies of a mosasaur and a Tyrannosaurus; research, preparation and restoration of a large Triceratops skull; while working in an 'open lab' set up at the Dutch national museum (Naturalis Biodiversity Center) for educational and outreach purposes.

education.field_of_study: Biology & Earth Life and Climate minor

projects.title: Paleopathology of Tyrannosaurus rex (Naturalis specimen)
projects.description: Description and subsequent diagnoses of the various pathologies found on the 'Dutch' Tyrannosaurus rex. The specimen was found by colleagues of Naturalis Biodiversity Center in collaboration with Black Hills Institute, in Montana in 2013. The paleopathological research will be conducted with the aid of the LUMC (Leids Universitair Medisch Centrum, Leiden, The Netherlands). One thing is clear, this aging female specimen has quite the story to tell.

contributors.headline: PhD candidate Palaeobiology of Thalattosauriformes at University of Zurich

projects.title: Preparation of Protoceratops
projects.description:
Preparation of a Protoceratops excavated during Roy Chapman Andrews'  2nd expedition in Mongolia in 1923. Recently re-discovered in the Mineralogisch-Geologisch Museum, Delft, Netherlands. Obtained in the period between 1940-1957 from the American Museum of Natural History, New York via trade (most likely in return for Timor fossils). 
The fossil consists of a large section of the jaw and skull of a young Protoceratops from the Djadochta ''red beds'' (Campanian of Shabarakh Usu).

projects.title: Mosasaur preparation
projects.description:
Preparation of a large mosasaur (NHMM2012072), with an estimated length of 13m, from the Maastrichtian type locality (ENCI quarry, near Maastricht, The Netherlands). Mosasaur ‘’Carlo’’, as it is known locally, was discovered on September 10th by a quarry employee (Carlo Brauer) in the flint-rich Lixhe 3 Member (Gulpen Formation, Maastrichtian). Preparation is still ongoing by a group of (experienced) volunteers, however the material so far includes: partial jaw sections, a (distorted) premaxilla, a pterygoid, an angular, and multiple elements of the axial skeleton. The taphonomic setting is unlike the normal pattern generally observed higher in the section, as individual bones are scattered over a wide area; bones are often distorted, and their surface heavily abraded. 
This mosasaur is most likely Prognathodon-like based on the morphology of the heterodont dentition, which resembles that of Prognathodon sectorius (previously L(e)iodon sectorius), features including: a swollen base in tooth outline, labiolingually flattened crowns and sharp carinae. Based on the stratigraphy, the given age estimate of 67.83 Ma, means that it is 1.5 Myr older than the Prognathodon saturator (or ‘Bèr’). It is unlikely, however if this turns out to be Mosasaurus hoffmanni than it would be the oldest known specimen.

(from:
Schulp, A.S. and Jagt, J.W.M. 2013. ‘’Carlo’’, A new Prognathodon-like mosasaur from the type Maastrichtian. In: 4th Triennial International Mosasaur Meeting, May 20-25, Dallas Texas, Polcyn, M.J. and Jacobs, L.L. eds. )

projects.title: Dyrosaurid crocodyliform (Dyrosaurus?) research
projects.description:
''Identification and research on the lifestyle, habit and functional morphology of a dyrosaurid crocodyliform from the Ypresian of the phosphatic deposits of the Oulad Abdoun Basin of Morocco. Most likely concerning Dyrosaurus maghribensis, this was mistakenly identified as Phosphatosaurus gavialoides Bergounioux 1955, the latter being an extinct genus of early Eocene crocodylomorph known from Tunisia and Mali. 
The specimen consists of 4 pieces, ranging from 50 cm to over a meter in length, comprising much of the axial skeleton and a virtually complete skull. It is encased in a secondary matrix (i.e. added later on) wrapped in a plaster cover. Preservation of the specimen is excellent and little additional work was done to the specimen. It was obtained in December of 2002 and registered in Museon and given the specimen number #228050. 
This relatively new Dyrosaurus species is currently only known from Morocco (Jouve, et al. 2006). It can be distinguished from D. phosphaticus (the only other species in the genus), present in contemporaneous levels of Algeria and Tunisia, by several autapomorphies, including a smooth dorsal margin of the parietal and widely opened choanae. Phylogenetic research (using 47 taxa and 234 morphological features), place the dyrosaurids as the sister taxon of pholidosaurids, the latter including Elosuchus, Sarcosuchus, Terminonaris and Pholidosaurus, and the thalattosuchians. Phylogenetic problems surrounding the longirostrine clade remain, and the blurry evolutionary relationships amongst the crocodyliforms can only be solved with more analyses and findings.''

Special thanks to Dr. Stéphane Jouve and Dr. Nathalie Bardet for help with identification.

(from:
Jouve, S., Iarochène, M., Bouya, B., and Amaghzaz, M. A new species of Dyrosaurus (Crocodylomorpha, Dyrosauridae) from the early Eocene of Morocco: phylogenetic implications. The Linnean Society of London, Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 148, pp. 603-656)

projects.title: Ichthyosaur (?Leptonectes) research
projects.description:
Research on the lifestyle and functional morphology of a large ichthyosaur. 

A fossil of an ichthyosaur (?Leptonectes), composed of 8 separate pieces: the skull composed of 2 pieces, the body consisting of 5 parts, and the tail section. The latter is a mere cast, most likely from another ichthyosaur present in the collection of the museum in Bristol, the rest is comprised of actual fossil material. Both the front paddles and the rear are attached to the body, the former have a width of 155cm and the latter of 68cm. The total skull length was 120 cm, completing the total length to 575cm.
The ichthyosaur (registered as Leptopterygius sp., #96270) was purchased in 1989 by the educational museum in The Hague, The Netherlands (Museon). This ichthyosaur originates from the Church Cliffs, Lyme Regis, and is exquisitely preserved in three dimensions (which is quite rare for this locality). It was conserved in a large chalk concretion, in barely hardened clayish deposits, which allowed 3D preparation by Bagnoli, S. The estimated age was noted as Lower Jurassic, Hettangian (~200 Ma).     
The complete weight of the fossil was around 750kg before preparation and currently weighs up to 190kg. The preparation process, including acid treatment of the chalk concretion, has taken roughly 7 months to be completed.

projects.title: Preparation of an ?elasmosaurid vertebra from the Maastrichtian type locality
projects.description:
Plesiosauroid (?) fossil preparation (volunteer)An isolated centrum, most likely from a Plesiosauroid (Elasmosauridae?). Discovered in the collection of the company mining for limestone in the quarry of Sibbe (near Maastricht, the Netherlands). 

'' Isolated skeletal remains of elasmosaurid plesiosaurs from the upper Upper Maastrichtian of the type area are a rarity. Especially when compared to their relatively common occurrence in the oceanic waters near California and Morocco of that age ( or even hadrosaurid dinosaur remains even though this represents a marine setting!).''

(from:
E.W.A. Mulder, N. Bardet, P. Godefroit & J.W.M. Jagt, Elasmosaur remains from the Maastrichtian type area, and a review of latest Cretaceous Elasmosaurs, 2000)

contributors.headline: PhD candidate Palaeobiology of Thalattosauriformes at University of Zurich

projects.title: Preparation/ restoration of Triceratops
projects.description:
Preparation and restoration of a large Triceratops (originally identified as T cf. brevicornis, most likely T. prorsus) which was badly damaged during transport from the Peabody Museum to the Mineralogisch-Geologisch Museum, of the Technical university of Delft (The Netherlands). This fossil consists of over 600 individual pieces held together by plaster, chicken wire and mesh. Previously preparated and treated by Dr. Kruizinga (estimated to have taken over a year to reconstruct). 
This fossil was obtained via trade in return for fossils from the Dutch colony of Timor. This specimen originated from the Cretaceous deposits termed the Lance-Formation from Lightning Creek (Wyoming, U.S.A., Maastrichtian). Collected in 1891 by J.B Hatcher.

company.name: Naturalis Biodiversity Center (NBC, Leiden, the Netherlands)

profile_positions.company: Naturalis Biodiversity Center (NBC, Leiden, the Netherlands)
profile_positions.title: External researcher

profile_positions.description:
Preparation of marine reptiles from the Maastrichtian type locality. Especially, Mosasaur ''Carlo'', discovery made in Sept. 2012 in ENCI quarry Maastricht, aged 67,83 million years old (Late Cretaceous). http://www.nhmmaastricht.nl/engels/index2.htm
At the same time looking more closely at pathologies in mosasaurs (and paleopathology in general), including the spectacular deformities of this mosasaur specimen.
profile_positions.title: Maastrichtian marine reptile (Msc) Research (volunteer) and fossil Preparation

profile_positions.description: Supervision and coordination of a new dinosaur laboratory, that is completely open to the public, for work on our new dinosaur specimens (multiple Triceratops) for several exhibitions.
profile_positions.title: (Co-) Chief preparator dinosaur lab

profile_positions.description: Working on dinosaurs recently obtained from the Mineralogisch-Geologisch Museum, Delft, The Netherlands. These include a partial skull of a young Protoceratops discovered during the Central Asiatic Expeditions of the early 1920s, and a damaged and subsequently repaired Triceratops skull from the Peabody Museum. Both are most likely obtained via trade in exchange for fossils from the Dutch colony Timor. Furthermore, a sneak preview of the research on the 'Dutch' T. rex that was recovered during a joint effort of members of the Naturalis Biodiversity Center and those of the Black Hills Institute, in Montana in 2013.
profile_positions.title: (Msc) researcher and Fossil preparator

profile_positions.description: collection, registration and curation of the fossil biodiversity of the Miocene (Dam Fm.) and Eocene (Dammam and Rus Fm.) deposits of Qatar. Fieldwork, preparation, curation and collection registration of fossils and provide scientific and curatorial information so as to be display ready for the new geology exhibit in the Qatar Museum of Natural History (Geology Hall in the National Museum).
profile_positions.title: Paleontology consultant, geology exhibit, qatar museums, doha

profile_positions.description: Working on various marine reptiles including mosasaurs, ichthyosaurs, and a dyrosaurid crocodyliform for the new 'Dino Jaws' exposition, starting Oct 10th 2014.
profile_positions.title: Marine reptile (Msc) research (volunteer)
